title: 103_hr4512
content: The "Welfare to Work Act of 1994" may be cited as the short title. The Congress acknowledges the importance of the Act. The Congress recognizes the need to create entry-level jobs for welfare recipients to transition into permanent employment, emphasizing the value of work experience in the private sector. A one-year tax credit is proposed to incentivize businesses to hire AFDC recipients and break the cycle of welfare dependency. To support the transition of AFDC recipients into permanent employment, a one-year tax credit is proposed for businesses that hire these individuals, aiming to break the cycle of welfare dependency. A one-year tax credit is proposed for businesses that hire AFDC recipients to support their transition into permanent employment and break the cycle of welfare dependency. This involves amending the Internal Revenue Code to include a refundable credit for hiring AFDC recipients. A one-year tax credit is proposed for businesses hiring AFDC recipients to aid their transition into permanent employment. The credit allows for 50% of qualified first-year wages up to $6,000 and 25% for wages between $6,000 and $12,000. Qualified first-year wages are defined as wages for services rendered within the first year of employment, with limitations if the individual worked for other employers during that period. The term 'qualified wages' refers to wages paid to qualified former AFDC recipients by the employer during the taxable year. A 'qualified former AFDC recipient' is an individual certified by the designated local agency as a member of a family receiving benefits under a State plan approved under part A of title IV of the Social Security Act before their employment with the employer. The term 'qualified former AFDC recipient' refers to an individual who was receiving benefits under a State plan approved under part A of title IV of the Social Security Act before their employment with the employer. No credit is allowed for wages paid to a qualified former AFDC recipient who replaces an employee terminated without cause. Technical amendments are made to certain sections of the Code. Technical amendments are made to certain sections of the Code, including amending subsection (a) of section 280C and paragraph (2) of section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. The table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code is also amended. The amendments made by this section apply to individuals who start working for the employer after the enactment of this Act.
